I slept until a little after daylight. After breakfast we moved into the woods and stayed until in the afternoon. This is a beautiful woods and Hezekiah and I have been wandering through it during the day. After noon we reported to Army headquarters and were assigned to the Second Corps: reported to the Second Corps head quarters and were ordered to the Second Division. We went into the woods while the Captain went to find the division head quarters. When he returned we were permitted to lie down and sleep all night, this was a most welcome announcement. 
Saturday June 11th  I awoke just after daylight. Our brigade

being on the front line in plain view of the enemy we have not joined it yet. Our advanced line is here about forty rods from that of the enemy in other places it is not more than a fourth of that distance. Coleman cam over to see us this morning. My heroic friend) Archabald has at last been wounded a minnie ball passed through his thigh. And the inevitable old Jake Fisher has also been hurt. This Old Jake as he is called is a man about 40 years of age he has wandered about the world a good deal, and is excessively fond of smoking he brought with him when he came into the service a favorite pipe of red pipe stone. A shell broke his highly prized pipe, and injured his jaw at the same time. He said: "I wouldn't a cared a damn if the sons of bitchs had'nt'a broke my pipe." Picket firing is going on all the time. And shell are frequently exchanged 
Sunday June 12th  We joined our old brigade last night. The enemy have been throwing a few shells, occasionally during the day, the shell passing mainly

about forty rods to the right of our brigade. We have had a meeting today which was more largely attended than such meetings were won't to be in more quiet times. Is it not possible; nay, extremely probable that this long continued battle which has now laster more than a month, has had the effect to bring many to reflect on the uncertainty of human life? I have observed more than once that some hardened sinners will cease swearing and become pensive on the approach of danger others became more reckless than ever. And one acknowledged to me that he prayed on entering the battle of Gettysburg. But in those days when I was an atheist I never thought of such a thing but every battle which I have entered since I have become convinced of the existence of a great God has had the effect to humble me. One of the 4th Mich was here today, an acquaintance of Hezekiahs. He gave us an account of the late battles. He says that the old

soldiers have resolved to charge no more breastworks. The story of an old soldier always differes from that of a new recruit or a reporter the old soldiers tell us that many of these charges here have been useless slaughters of men on works that could never be carried by charge but could be easily flanked and that after slaughtering thousands of men flanking was at last resorted to, now I believe this is all true and moreover, about one year ago I could believe that there never was a better army than this. It is not so now. we are sadly degenerated though our numbers are as nearly twice as great I verily believe that such an army as we took to Gettysburg would flog us. Now something has caused this, and that something is the soldiers have been slaughtered as they have believed uselessly, no matter whether the slaughter was useless or not they believe it to have been so and they will not fight as they once would. The rebel Army is in much the same condition, if either army can have an open field fight it will do well enough, but

neither will charge with any vigor. In truth we have not that spirit, vim, and determination that so characterized the army on the two preceding years. We are now under marching orders  Monday June 13th  Just after sundown last night we fell back into the least advanced of our lines of works and lay there until quite late in the night. In the mean time our troops in the advanced line of works were withdrawn and we all moved off toward our left flank. I presume we are bound for the James. While we were laying in the works last night we had an opportunity to watch some mortar practice. The enemy were shelling a position of ours about a mile to the right of our brigade Although eww could barely hear the mortar, yet the report of the shell was fully as heavy, and not unlike, that of a riled 10 pounder. The course of the shell being nearly toward us thier motion appeared very slow, something like the falling of a spark of fire. Just at daylight this morning there came near being a panic caused by so slight a thing as

a horse falling off a bank and rolling down into the road those who were near him jumped out of the way. the next seeing them jump so suddenly did likewise, and the whole succeeding lines did in the same manner. Most panics arise from something about as simple as this. A danger however great as not terrible if we know what it is, but some unknown uncertain and mysterious nothing will often strike brave men with terror. There is a great difference between terror and fear. danger we calmly resolve to meet, but sudden mystery seizes us and unbinds our nerves and we are carried by it in spite of reason. As the dread of a snake is more terrible that that of any wild beast. We arrived at Long Bridge just after eight this morning and bivoaced? for a few hours. About two oclock we crossed the Chicahominny we found here some cypress I picked a few leaves and intend sending them to mother. image functioning as an asterisk We guarded the rear and reached camp near Charles City C.H.? about midnight. 
image functioning as an asterisk I carried these cypress leaves through Andersonville Prison, brought them home, and gave them to Mother. Their imprint still remains in my old Diary. (1916.)

Tuesday June 14th.    We moved still nearer the C.H. this morning. Imson and I visited the old building, found it entirely empty. When our army passed this place in 62 they carried off all the boards as relics? (see page 47) The country is very beautiful and is open In August 62 when we were here we lived very highly but now all is barren and desolate. In the afternoon we marched down to the James river crossed on the M.S. steam Transport  Hellen Getty, while we were on the dock Gen. Grant came off the boat passed through our battalion and mounted his horse near by; this is the first time I ever saw the Lieut. General. The country on the south side of the James is very fertile and beautiful we passed one field of corn which excelled anything I have seen this year We went out to the front and lay down in line of battle during the night. I was on guard we are in a thick pine under brush, (written on the 15)  Wednesday June 15th   first day of siege)   This day will long be remembered as the day on which Gen. Grant in command of the armies of the Republic sat down before Petersburg. We marched about 11 oclock

A.M. and about 11 P.M. we arrived in front of Petersburg, and found that our men had taken three lines of the enemy's works during the afternoon. Second day of Siege. Thursday June 16th. We dug rifle pits during the latter part of last night. The works here are very strong the drakes charge on this part of the line and took three lines of works and some artilery but no prisoners as they retaliated here for the Fort Pillow massacre. Shelling and skirmishing has been continued at intervals during the day. I am very sleepy and tired but I can afford to bear hardships when there is an end in view. At about 6 P.M. our forced advanced and drove the enemy some distance at the present time, 7 P.M., there is a hill, we are as yet lying as reserve in our pits.   Friday June 14th  Third day of Siege. Morning, Last night after dark I went in charge of a detail to draw ratings and did not get back until one A.M. In the fight last night our forces drove the enemy out of two lines of pits: the enemy afterwards made two charges to drive our forces from them but were repulsed each time.

Evening

     There has been hard fighting on the left to-day. It is hard that Burnside was successful in taking three forts. late in the evening the enemy charged on an mess but were again repulsed. There is a movement now gaining on but our brigade yet remains in the marks. The indications are that we will charge to-morrow. 
     Saturday June 18th

Fourth day of Lége

      We moved before day-light this morning. Charged but forward the first line of mask abandoned. We hashed forward about three fourths of a mile where we found them matting for us as succeeded in expelling them from this line also. 
      After a time our battalion was de----- as skirmishes and had some hot mark. We got a fashion behind one of those old pure trenches peculiar to Virginia. But  touring to the recklessness of our men One had two men killed and one officer and fire --- rounded. This was all needless but the old soldiers wanted to show this.

recruits how brave they were and of course the recruits were found to be as daring as they. But alas?  I know full well that they will find work enough yet.  When we got this position the enemy held another very close to it and on a little higher ground. And besides this they had some sharp shooters at some distance to our right who had a flanking fire on us.  Though we were partly sheltered from their fire by the trees that grew along our fence row.  Now had our men laid in the trench to load and unclear only rose to fire we would most likely have driven them from their position without loss.  Our company acted more sensibly than the other unclear to the example of Berdan Imtra? and a few other old soldiers to whom the recruits look for a patron?.  But we had a Sergeant of course an old soldier but a foolhardy wretch unclear for a commission who while showing his bravery in a very foolish manner received a bullet in his head.  I could not say that it grieved me much to see him fall, for I reflected that we had better men.

who were in danger of losing their lives by his rashness and moreover, should he ever succeed in getting his commission he would be a tyrant and sacrifice the lives of his men for the sake of the further advancement.  Hence, I tried to submit to the will of Providence when he fell.  However, we eventually drove them from their position and advancing occupied it ourselves.  We are now within rifle shot of the city or nearly so but there is a woods and a strong line of works? between us and it.  The 6th Corps charged on the right at the same time that we advanced and got the enemy's fence row.  A charge was also made on a strong fort of the enemies just to our left but here was a most horrid and useless slaughter.  The 6th Corps at the same time trying to gain the enemy's main works was also repulsed.  This has been a bloody day and while we have gained some ground we have also lost many men.  Captain Farwell has been whiskey unclear all day.  Our recruits have acted splendidly but oh! if we are ever broken.  I fear we can never rally.

We got a mail tonight and Hezckin? received a letter which informs us that Ned is going with General Sully's (Sullivan's) expedition to the plains this summer.  unclearwill we be widely scattered, one facing grim death on the fields of Georgia.  One farming in Minnesota, one adventuring on the plains of the Northwest and then battling on Virginia's soil.
Sunday June 19th
5th Day of Siege
We are still laying where yesterday's battle left us.  We have good unclear which we dug with our bayonets and plates last night.  we have been shooting at the rebels all day but I don't expect we have hurt many of them.  The fort was to the left which was so foolish unclear charged yesterday is about half mile from us and as we have a flanking fire on it it is our sport to elevate our rifles and make the unclear rebs feel uneasy there.  Of course we cannot hurt them much but we can make them feel so bad.  If we only had a position here for artillery, we could easily take it.  No on in our battalion has been hurt today up the present hour (6:30 p.m.) I have slept considerable of the time today.

Monday June 20th
6th Day of Siege 
The enemy have opened fire on us from their batteries across the Appomattox.  Their fire unclear us our batteries also unclear other parts of their lines.  Our firing directly in front has been less brisk than yesterday but we still continue to pass shots out to them occasionally while the 19th Marine? which has a flanking fire on one of their positions keeps up a continual fuselage, this beyond doubt is very annoying to the poor rebs for my experience goes to show that an unclear fire is much the most to be dreaded.  That a citizen may understand this, you'll explain, if you have unclear in your front they will protect you so long as the fire come from that direction; but if, the fire comes on your flank what is to protect you?  Besides, a bullet coming from the enemy's front, if it comes too high, is harmless, but if it comes on your flank, it will pass on down your lines and finally unclear among your men.  Again, if it comes with force enough it may harm more than one man.  I was pleased at a remark made

by one of our recruits today as the bullets were passing over our heads constantly and occasionally a shell from their batteries on our flank.  He looked around with a unclear countenance and and relieved his mind as follows:  "When I was in Minnesota, I could hear nothing but three hundred dollars bounty; but here I can hear nothing but bombs and bullets."  We have had no casualties in our battalion yet today, but the 6th Corps just to our right is carrying men to the rear all the time.
Thursday June 21st
Seventh day of siege
As I am now opening on a new phase of my soldier experience I shall henceforth unclear word for word from my Diary then comment afterwards.  "We were relieved from the trenches last night by a part of the 6th Corps and slept from 10pm until late this morning.  We had just pitched our tents this morning when the order came to "pack up", and we were soon on the march.  The weather is excessively hot and the dust intolerable.  Our sufferings are such as no citizen would believe could be born.  I have just made up my mind that one day of war is more to be deplored than a whole age of ordinary evils.  Ever after

this I shall do all in my power to discourage war.  Just about 4 o'clock this afternoon we came when the enemy and lost two men by sharpshooters.  O, I am sick of war.  If God spares my life I will always be its enemy.  What first unclear man to slaughter his fellow man?  What giant crime have those to answer for who have brought on this war.Night, another man wounded thus we are going, not in the rage of battle as Gettysburg but stealthy, slowly, unclear and fatally the deadly missiles thin our ranks.  I was on unclear all night and many bullets struck in from of the little pit where I was laying.  Our men worked all night on the works/marks?  I have copied the above from my diary to show that coming events do sometimes cast their shadows before I shall do so again in my unclear of the unclear a day which will long be remembered by me.

Wednesday June 22nd
8th Day of Siege
"We lay in our rifle pits the 19th Marine is losing men all the time by sharpshooters. A little after noon the enemy opened a battery enfilading our pit.  This battery is in a strong fort and a commanding position.  I am still more disgusted with war.  I wish this cruel war was over."
Evening
"Why have I felt so heavily for a few days?  The enemy have broken the left flank of our line and remaining in the trenches too long I was taken prisoner.  The skinning process so often described by returned prisoners was carried out to the letter. After we were well skinned we were taken to Petersburg and there lodged in an old brink building which was formerly used for God knows what.  Of course there was not great rejoicing in town over the arrival of a few Yanks and some of our men tried to unclear favor of the rebs by abusing the government?.  Those are the words of my diary.  Now I will proceed to detail.  On the 21st we

We began our movement toward the left and arrived in the evening at a place known as Jerusalem Plank Rods near the Wilton Rail Road. Here our battalion advanced as Skirmishers, having moved through a piece of woods we were in plain view of the enemy's position. Capt. Farrell was evidently somewhat intoxicated, we took our position in the edge of the woods and dug pits where we remained all night. We had thus far lost only three men in this move. About daylight four pieces of artilery were brought up and took position on the left of our battalion and between it and the third brigade. As has been before stated just on our right was a strong out but there was no embrasures opened toward us. During the entire forenoon, we could see the rebels digging away and preparing the fort for firing down our lines meanwhile a few rebel soldiers were seen moving about in our front unclear going to the right at another to the left but our right was threatened by the fort and maneuvers seemed to indicate that they intended attacking us there. What were we doing all this time? were we acting like soldiers?

No, a whiskey rather had been issued most of the officers and many of the soldiers were drunk.  [Caft], Farrel had had whiskey enough in him to make a [brace] fool of him, for he it know he is a canard and can not face danger without whiskey to strengthen his nerves.  But now, being well filled with whiskey.  He would hoist his foot above the beast works.  "Say Johnny, give me a flesher," meaning a flesh nomad.  I often wished from the bottom of my heart that they would send out a shell in answer to his prayer and take his foot.  Not for any malice I bore the poor fool but I knew that noble men were yet to perish on his account.  again there was a general called for shot Gen. Runy, who was in command of the Cops, who got his Major General straps since years since because  his disobedience brought him to notice.  He too was drunk or acted like a drunk man.  Oh, it does my soul good to think that I can record these things now, and no superior officer can order me to shut my mouth.  Gen Bussy giving orders to the colonel in

command of the second brigade. "Colonel, advance your brigade till you develope something you haint developed anything yet." Now, if I am any judge of the tones of a drunken man, this order was given by a drunken man's voice. I turned to some of the recruits and remarked, "It is my opinion that brigade will not advance far before it developes something." As I saw all these signs of a coming reverse I grew blue. I told the soldiers that when the ball? opened I would run the first fire. Had I fulfilled my promise it would have saved me many a unclear day in prison. Well sure enough the brigade developed something the enemy passed a couple of brigades, around its left (without a picket) and into our rear, they there attacked the brigade, drove it back, they at the same time opened thier battery with renewed vigor on our right and threatened an attack in that direction. finally as the brigade which had developed on our left fell back, and being in the woods hid from our view, the bullets began to come

down our left flank. Then here Farrell sprang to his feet. "Boys they are flanking us!" and away he went without giving an order. The recruits and old soldiers soon followed thier leader. O, Then I thought of the old regt. and Sully, we had stopped two similar stampedes and could do it again, but alas! What are we now, degenerate? A few recruits and forty old soldiers are not equal to 300 heroes like the old regiment, and, besides, our commander is a cowardly drunkard. Well when they all run I ran with them; but hearing a shout that the captain wanted to bring of his artilery (The capt of Art. I mean.) I called to Berdan and Berg who were near me and we returned to the pit, fired a few shots. Bullets were still coming from the left; but I saw no enemy very near. I remarked to Berdan that I believed that we could hold the works yet. He said he didnt know about that. This was spoken as though he saw something, but as I was busy loading my gun, I replied we can hold them or go to Richmond. His answer was "I'll die before I'll be taken prisoner" and I suppose he ran as he spoke, for when I was done loading

I raised my eyes and the enemy's colors were on our artilery just a few steps to my left. I fired and started to run, but found that I had delayed too long. The enemy were on every side of me. "Throw down that gun." I obeyed the order. "Get over the beast works here you damed Son of a nitch." I could do nothing but quietly obey. Thus was I sure enough bound for Richmond, though I never expected to go there when I made that reply to Berdan.   Thursday June 23rd  ell, I suppose the history of the siege, so far as I am individually concerned, has now come to an untimely end: And the next thing in order will be the history of my imprisonment. We joined a large number o other prisoners who were taken last night but who had gone by another route. among them we found several of our battalion the following are the names: Sergt Major Pride Sergt May Co A. Sergt Dyer Co B. Corporals Clark, Seward, Reed, Aleprs, and Prine all of Co A. Privates, Pribble, Perkins, Carpenter, Baker, Rider, Harry, Co A.

Berg, Parker, Hamilton, Sullivan, Abraham, Whalen, Storoloff, and the unworthy writer; of Co B.  We passed through Petersburg this morning. We sang "Rally around the Flag" as we passed along. The women are in an ecstasy of delight over the Yankee Prisoners. But when we halted for a spell, they kindly brought us water without waiting to be asked for it. This should be remembered to thier credit. The city of Petersburg is rather more pleasant, neater, and to all appearances ahead of most Southern cities. One particular feature of the city is that it is better shaded than any other city it has been my lot to enter, and this feature is truly a pleasant one. Our names have been taken we are on a sort of island in the Appomatox in which we have bathed, we are hearing of our artilery. We are in all about 1200. They have just called the names of about 800 who are to be sent to Richmond tomorrow.   Friday June 24th   About 3 oclock this morning we marched down to the depot where we took the cars, and miserable

dilapidated concerns they are; fit? emblems of the Southern Confederacy.  We arrived in Richmond about 12 o'clock.  Here a still more rigid search is going on and greenbacks must go the way of all living.  We are at the famous Sibby.  One good feature of this prison is that the floors are clean, and unclear boxes are plentiful.  We have drawn this evening two pieces of corn bread each about five inches long and an in and a half think, and two inches wide; how long this is expected to last I do not know."

 At the time when I wrote the above I was very careful not to say anything against our treatment lest the rebels should take my diary, read it and confiscate it.  But the man, who was in command of Sibby, (Dick Turner I think) was the biggest ruffian I ever saw.  I could not help thinking I was under charge of some old pirate.  When we were searched most of the boys succeeded in hiding at least a part of their money.  Some had large slate buttons on their coats and taking them apart each would very handily hold a $20 note then putting them together the buttons

on their coats were each worth twenty dollars.  Others concealed money in their pork of which we had just drawn four days rations just before we were taken.  I have written this account of the way money was saved that the reader may not be surprised when I talk of money hereafter as no strange thing in prison.
Saturday June 25th
They have unclear to us a small piece of bacon another piece of bread the same size of those issued last night and half pint of bean soup with plenty of beans in it.  (I mean a fair proportion of the soup was beans).  I have been reading in the Testament; I have done so every day since I was taken prisoner and if such is the will of God I shall continue so to do until I am free.  I have a grammar with me and hope to find time to unclear that some, but as yet I have been making unclear for sleep last? in the late unclear.  Our names and places of birth were taken today.  It is rumored that we ae to be paroled.  I would be glad to get away from this place.

Sunday June 26th

 I read in the Testament I have come to the conclusion that the bread we receive here will weigh nearly a pound though from its bulk it should weigh only half that amount.  We were removed to Bell Island.  Here we received old and miserably unclear Wedge and Ball tents. I will not tell one thing worse than it is.  We were permitted to take a good bath in the James River.  I read in the Testament and studied grammar.  We are divided into messes of fifty each mess has five tents.

Monday June 27th

  Our rations of bread not quite so large as at Sibby but of a little better quality.  I ate mine more soup but not so many beans in it.  unclear meat and that too of a very poor quality.  I ate all my rations at one meal and could have eaten twice as much.  Our coffee has not entirely given out yet, and we have a little of Uncle Sam's pork left.  I read in the Testament, study grammar and slept.

Tuesday June 28th
"It rained last night and the tent leaked miserably.  Afterwards the wind arose and the

tent blew over for it is too rotten to stand.  Our rations the same as yesterday except soup and of that we received a double quantity."
If I had made the same discovery on the 27th that I did on the 28th I think I should have escaped on the night of that rain.  We were surrounded by a ditch and from the camp there was a passage down to the river, here across the ditch was a bridge, near to it stood a rebel guard.  Now on this dark rainy night I could take a stick for a gun.  crawl under the bridge and wait until the guard was relieved, crawl slyly out behind the relief guard as they were halted to relieve the sentinel.  Take my stand as one of the guard, march off wit the relief fall out just before we should reach the guard house, swim the James and try for our lives.  This I plotted and now resolved to wait for another rainy night.  But before that came we moved as will be seen if you will read another day.
Wednesday June 29th
We drew the usual rations of head and meat, but no soup.  We then moved off got aboard the cars? and started for Lynchburg.  The cars? were miserably crowded and no water.  We arrived in Lynchburg about midnight having been about 18 hours on the way.

Thursday June 30th
Morning
We did not get of the cars until daylight this morning.  We then crossed over to and island and are here yet.  We have drawn no rations yet but I traded my portfolio for a piece of corn bread.  And my gold pen for which I had no holder for a quart of meal.  One of the prisoners unclear off the cars last night and though he was twice fired at escaped may God speed him to our lines.
Thursday June 30th
Evening
We drew hard bread said to be four days rations, eighteen crackers, a little thicker but not more substance than one of Uncle Sam's crackers, if these are for four days we have drawn just about one third as much as we would in our lives for the same length of time.  We also drew some bacon which is pretty good unclear.  This is also to last four days about half what we would get from our government for the same time. 1/4 of a pound of breads looks small to march a day upon but I suppose we can stand it.  Mr. Storaloff? has given out and has been sent to one of the hospitals.

We left Lynchburg about 4 p.m. As we marched through the town I observed that Lynchburg is a dirty place, the sheets are filthy and rough.  It is situated among the mountains and hills.  There are a great many hospitals here.  Several of them are filled with wounded from our army.  I noticed one very fine building on the right, south of town:  this building is at present used as a hospital, what it was before the war, I know not.  It appears that General Hunter in his late advance crossed to the south side of the James and approached within a mile and a half of them?.  We passed over ground today where some of the fighting had taken place.  I have read some in the Testament today.
Friday July 1st 1864
We camped last night in a fine little valley about 5 miles from Lynchburg.  The country which we passed on the evening of the 30th and the morning of the 1st was hilly and mountainous resembling unclear Valley.  In the afternoon today the country became more level some of the scenery is beautiful.  The land here is very poor.  We camped at night on the Stanton River.  distance marched 20 miles.  The Stanton River is a narrow rapid, clear, and beautiful mountain stream here and we had a nice bath in its delightful waters.

Saturday July 2nd 1864  We marched about 20 miles, and camped in a nice place we marched so fast that the rebel guards gave out so that they were obliged to call out the citizens to guard us. If these are real specimens of rebel soldiers I don't see how the southern confederacy has lasted so long. The country much the same as that we passed in the afternoon, but we may often travel ten miles in this region without seeing water." In those days I was again plotting my escape. When we would stop in the woods I would try picking huckleberries, but I believe a certain old reb mistrusted my design for he kept his eyes on me on all such occasions. 
Sunday July 3d  We marched about 15 miles to day, Passed through Pittsylvania C.H. a beautiful well? village. We have been in Pittsylvania County for the last two days I think. I had the hardest knock down to day that ever came in my experience. It was with a Sergt. belong to the 4th Vermont

I was pretty badly battered, perhaps, the worst of the two, but I gained my point which ought to satisfy me. I have learned since the fight that he is a bully. But that is a name for which I have no regard and when wronged by one of that stripe I will fight him a little quicker if any odds than any other character. 
Danville July 4th  We arrived here to-day and were crowded into prisons. The town is situated on a broad but shallow and rocky river. We have not received any rations yet to night although our rations which you remember were but 1/4 pound a day was to expire last night. We have marched about 16 miles to-day Mr Whallon gave out today. I guess we will not forget this fourth of July soon. I presume we will draw rations yet to-night. 
Danville July 5th  We drew bread and meat last night after dark more of it and better quality than that which we received at either Belle Island or Libby. And again this morning we received bread. as our march is now ended I will state before leaving the subject that several of

our men escaped on the march many were fired at but I guess none were hit. The weather has been warm. 
Evening Tuesday July 5th   "We drew bread again to day and a larger quantity than ever before, I read in the Testament and studied grammar." As I sat on the floor a feeling of almost heavenly pleasure stole over me and last so for nearly an hour. I know not why it was but I have never felt more calm and quiet pleasure in all my life, perhaps it was given in mercy as a prelude to the weary? months that were to follow. Later in the day we took the cars for Greensboro. The car was so Shackling? and they ran so fast that I expected every minute to be mashed to atoms. but so it was we came safely through to Greensboro, where we took another train for Charlotte. 
Wednesday July 6th  "We arrived in Charlotte today about noon, and here we are bivouaced and waiting for Rears? as the "Guards" call them. We have drawn the days prison rations of hard bread and bacon.

Thursday July 7th  We were called up about midnight last night, and crowded into the cars but we did not leave Charlotte until eight this morning. We passed through Waynesboro to Columbia. This day has been wretched enough, we have had a guard on our car who has never seen the front, and who takes delight in the sufferings of a Yank we have been crowded so thick that we were obliged to stand or sit with our legs drawn up so close that we could not rest. Besides, we have suffered for water. We had on our car a recruit named John about 6 foot two inches high, a green Pennsylanian. While our tired limbs were aching and we were all naturally longing for an opportunity to expand them, John with the most doleful look of despair and a tone of the deepest agony that seemed to come from the foundation of his heart groaned out, "Oh I do wish I was out on a nice green grass plot. I'd just sprawl out." Our woes were forgotten for a moment and a roar of laughter burst from every one in the car. At length all was hushed again, and all seemed looking into the gloomy prospect before

us: not a word had been spoken for an hour, when John again opened out, "Oh! boys you have no idea how I have suffered!" Another roar of laughter succeeded, John looked around with an injured air as though he thought we enjoyed his sufferings. But the idea was truly laughable that we who were suffering the same evils as he could form no conception of his woes. 
Friday July 8th  "We changed cars about midnight last night and to-day we came to Augusta Ga." Just at dark on the 8th we had some water and got no more until about 9 oclock on the morning of the 9th though the weather is excessively hot and we were crowded as thick as could be in the cars. (Chivalry?)
Sunday July 10th "We passed through Marion this morning and arrived in camp at Anderson 
By mistake I have left out the 9th on the 9th we lay in Augusta during the forepart of the day; And drank water to excess. After we arrived in Augusta we were permitted to "Sprawl" on the much desired "grass plot" It seemed to me on the 9th that I could drink water all the time and yet be thirsty.

about noon. Found Sam Wales in the Prison which is a miserable place indeed,"  We were formed into hundreds before we were taken inside the stockade. as our names were all to be taken this required some hours and as we stood in the hot sun over thirty fell in the ranks from exhaustion and the heat of the sun. 
And now for a few words about Andersonville Prison, or Camp Sumpter. Imagine a Stockade of pine logs cut twenty feet long five feet in the ground, and fifteen above the ground. this Stockade is a little over 80 rods long and a little over 40 rods wide, in all perhaps it contains 23 acres about 5 acres on the South end. (the stockad being longer from North to South) is habitable this 5 acres is sandy. Then runs a creek through the prison from west, to east, the valley of this creek is swampy and springy. along each of its margins have been dug wells. In many of these wells there are maggots but in some there is pretty good water The swamp is the rescepticle of the greater part of the filth of the camp and can be better imagined than described

the swamp contains 5 acres suffice it to say that it is six inches deep in filth and covered with maggots continually 
In the creek at all hours may be seen hundreds of skeletons bathing. The ground, about 13 acres, on the north side is higher and is clay. About a rod from the Stockade extending round the camp is a line significantly called the "dead line" which bids fair to become famous in history. This line where it stands is a fine board about 3 inches wide nailed on the top of stakes about two and a half feet high. Anyone seen between it and the stockade, is shot without warning, many times it is broken down and new prisoners coming in carelessly stray over and are shot. Others going insane and becoming tired of life go over on purpose to lose thier lives. When I first came into prison, I came near losing my life in the same way that others have done. As the prison was crowded, and seeing an open space, the railing being broken, I started to go over there, but fortunately one of the old prisoners called to me and warned me in time.

There is a market place in the prison at the north gate. and also a smaller one at the south gate. The north gate is in the west side of the stockade just on the hill as you go north from the creek; the south gate is also on the west side of the stockade just as you go south from the creek. We have a regular police force
sketch of prison noting locations of cookhouse, stockade, north gate, market, bakery, main street, south gate, creek, swamp - image

which was organized in consequence of robbers and murders having leagued together to raid on their more inoffensive neighbors. But a few weeks before I entered the prison a man was murdered and it was no uncommon thing for a man to be knocked down and robbed in open daylight. Six of these murders were hung on the 11th. Go to the market at almost any time of day but especially just after rations have been issued and you will see a sight that beggars description. every conceivable thing from a tent pole to a ration of meat is offered for sale in such language as the following. "Who wants to by the meat? Who wants a another glass of the nice sour beer? Plenty of pepper sauce in it. Who wants a tent pole? who has a ration of bread to trade for a ration of meat? Who wants to by the comb? Who wants to buy the tin cup? Who wants to buy the wood? and inconceivable other offers; as, tobacco, buttons, needles, thread blankets, tents, pens, ink, paper envelopes, postage stamps, and confederate money. Besides this market we have regular merchants

Who offer potatoes, apples, peaches, biscuit, tomatoes, eggs, pies, peas, and various other articles too numerous to mention, "all at the lowest cash prices." And there is much more money in prison than one would think. These rich merchants and the police, form a sort of aristocracy and hold communion with the rebels for the purpose of trade. After these remarks, I presume my Diary will be understood. and I now proceed with it
Monday July 11th  I lay around and read in the Testament. Six ruffians were hung for murder They had been tried by an impartial jury of prisoners just arrived, found guilty and sentenced to death and were hung just east of the south gate within the stockade. It has been raining today. and 13 of us have but two small blankets and two pieces about 8 feet wide for shelter. There are now about 30,000 in this prison and deaths average over 100 per diem.

Tuesday July 12th  It is cloudy and consequently pleasant to day I lay around and read in the Testament I am not well. The deceases which prevail most here are scurvy, diarhaea and dropsey. Besides the whole camp is poison and many of the prisoners being barefoot if they get a toe hurt a little it will take poison from the filthy ground and often rots off so that the most horrid sights of decaying flesh while yet alive are so common as to attract no attention. 
Wednesday July 18th  Lay around, read the Testament and talked with Sam Wales. When you lay down to sleep here maggots crawl all over you and swarms of flies torment you by day. 
Thursday July 14th  The rebels guarding us seem very uneasy to-day  Can it be that our forces are making a dash in this direction. I read in the Testament and lay around to day

Friday July 15th  Read the Testament. 
Saturday July 16th  Read the Testament. 
Sunday July 17th  I read in the Testament. Some of the boys had plotted to dig out and had thier tunnel nearly finished when a traitor betrayed them this morning receiving as a reward of his treason a half plug of tobaco. No sooner were the rebels gone out of the prison than he was caught by our men his head shaved and a letter T. branded on his forehead, and he was kicked and cuffed all over the prison every where he went men would rise and strike him nor did I see that he had one sympathizer. He could not have stood this long had not the rebels sent in a guard and taken him out. 
Monday July 18th I read in the Testament. It rained.

Tuesday July 19th Read in the Testament. 
Wednesday July 20th The rebels here got frightened and are fortifying. I rad in the Testament. 
Thursday July 21st Read in the Testament. 
Friday July 22d and Sat. 23d Read in the Testament
Sunday July 23d  Cold enough this morning to make the boys put on thier coats. This is pretty well for Georgia in July. I read in the Testament
Monday July 25th Read in the Testament and studied Grammar. It rained. 
Tuesday July 26th  Read in the Testament and studied Grammar. Rained again to-day.
Wednesday July 27th Read in the Testament and studied Grammar. 
Thursday July 28th  Mr. Staroloff, who it will be remembered I gave out at Lynchburg, came into

camp to-day A large number of prisoners came in from Shermans army to-day. The rebels are always scared out of thier wits every time new prisoners arrive lest we should get word out to them, and attack the camp. They fired shot over our heads to-day in order to intimidate us, which only had the effect of scaring thier own malitia guards til the nearly jumped off of thier stands. about these stands I neglected to state in my description of the prison that every five rods around the stockade is a post or stand raised above the top of the Stockade from this stand they look down on the camp. it is approached by a stair from the out side of the Stockade.
Friday July 29th  I read in the Testament. It rained. More prisoners came in to day some with an arm off and the wound not yet healed. This is chivalry. They are sent here to breathe this poison air and lie on this poison earth often without blankets, almost without clothing, by men who prate about civilized warfare and call us vandals, who feed and

and pet thier ruffians as though they were our own dear children. Oh! I wish I were free and had command of those camps in the north. I would put rebel officers in a condition to appreciate the luxuries which they have hitherto enjoyed at our hands. 
Saturday July 30th  Read in the Testament
Sunday July 31st  We had a discussion this morning as to which is the first day of the week Sergt. Major Pride holds that it is monday, and would not yield the point although we showed him an almanac in which it is plainly seen that the week begins on Sunday. One man was absent from roll call this morning and his rations for to-day were consequently stopped. Be it known that the rebels have roll call every morning and any one failing to attend loses his rations for that day. I read in the Testament.

Monday August 1st 1864
There is a great deal of talk about parole men are always starting rumors of anything they greatly desire.  Read in the Testament, rained a little.
Tuesday August 2nd
It rained hard today some of the Stonemans cavalry were brought in today they have been making a raid to near Macon.  Read in the Testament.
Wednesday August 3rd
They are removing some of the sick.  More of the Cavalry were brought in.
Thursday August 4th
Read in the Testament.  More reports about parole yesterday and today they have removed some of the sick.
Friday August 5th
Read in the Testament
Saturday August 6th
Read Psalms and Testament. We drew an extra ration of meal tonight.  Our rations have hither to consisted of about one pint of raw mush and two ounces of bacon. When

we have been so lucky as to draw bread instead of mush. The ration was somewhat larger.  Those who draw raw rations get plenty of meal but the wood is so scarce that they are lucky if they get it cooked.  The ration of wood is a piece about 3 feet long by two inches every other way to last three days.
Sunday July 7th
Read Psalms. unclear William Daily and Ephriam Thompson of the 5th Ind. Cavalry. Old neighbors of ours. They were captured near Macon in the late raid. There are great rumors of parole. We lost our bread ration tonight.
Monday August 8th
Read Psalms and bathed. It rained.
Tuesday August 9th
"Read Psalms. We got no rations today. We had the hardest raid today I ever saw. Part of the stockade fell down which gave the poor rebs great trouble had we discovered it a little sooner we might have charged their camp."  One of the effects of this rain was to clean the camp of

filth, mashing it down on to the scramp which was covered six inches deep in dirt from the hill on which we were camped.  Besides this a spring burst out between the "dead line" and stockade just south of the north gate.  There our men would go and fish out unclear by fastening their cups to a stick.  For some reason the rebels had humanity enough to permit the spring to be turned by a spout into the prison. From this spring came pure water enough for 5,000 men. On the whole this rain was deemed as a blessing sent us by a pitying Providence.
Wednesday August 10th
We drew half our former bread ration today and some peas full of unclear and hulls, sand and unclear, nothing tonight but fresh beef and a little salt.  The beans and bread were for yesterday.  Rained again today.  Read Psalms. Sergeant Major Pride and Hamilton quarreled and fought today.  Pride was notorious.
Thursday August 11th
Only part rations. Rained hard again today. Read Psalms. The fifty fifth Psalm is a description of this prison, time, and life line.

Friday August 12th
Read Psalms and also Christ's Sermon on the Mount. Rations continue short.
Saturday August 13th
Read Psalms and also in the New Testament. More rumors of parole, provisions continue scarce. A few thieves were flogged today. That is the punishment usually inflicted here for stealing.
Sunday August 14th
Read Psalms. More extensive rumors of parole. (I kept a regular account of parole rumors for a long time just to see how many times we would hear of it before it should come).
Monday August 15th
"Read Psalms. Rumors die away." While it does not do well to trust rumors in such places yet it is always best to engage in some hopeful cheerful conversation, and not sit like an owl brooding over your miseries.
Tuesday August 16th
I have at last recovered from the diarrhea with which I have been afflicted ever since my arrival here.

I took a walk about the stockade today our rations now are part bread and part beans and I trade my bread for beans or rather unclear stock peas and to this I ascribe my recovery to health.
Wednesday August 17th
"I read Psalms and went to sick call first to see how horrible it really is. And O my God! I pray that something may relieve this wretched mess."  There were men with great gaping wounds in which maggots were working and flies continually annoying. Here were skeletons with hollow glaring eyes staring vacantly around, reason having fled.  That meaningless look, who that has once beheld can ever forget.  Here were men with limbs swollen with scurvy turned black and blue and rotting from their frames. Others naked and covered with sores.  Here again between the dead line and stockade lay the dead who have been relieved from their sufferings within the last twenty-four hours.  These sick and wounded are all turned back to die within this horrid den, then be tumbled carelessly into a trench with cold and brutal remarks over his grave.  Northern mother, whose son perished

in Anderson or any other rebel prison would you know the manner of his death.  I have given it.  But I must yet tell you more about the death of your son.  And this is yet more painful to tell. He was most probably marched and jeered by his own comrades to the last hour of his life and when he dies there was most probably a fight for his clothing by his comrades. And another quarrel and perhaps a fight for the privilege of carrying him out that they might get some wood while out.  This I am compelled to record. It shows what men are when reduced to extremities. And while I morn these weaknesses of our nature I must confess that I approached much nearer to a brute than is now pleasant to reflect upon.  And I often congratulate myself that none of my brothers were with me lest I had shown myself selfish to them and had this thing to brood over during all my afterlife.  I have seen brothers grovel about rations, and curse each other.  Oh if these scenes will not humble the heart of man it is proud indeed. And now

as I write the old scenes come afresh before my eyes and my heart swells within my breast. I would now shed tears but alas! My last tear was shed when I returned home and learned of my brother's death in one of these cured prisons. Nor did a tear flow then until twelve hours after I received the intelligence. I presume I shall never shed another.
Thursday August 18th
I visited the market today and I will keep a sort of market report for a few days so that the reader may form an idea of prices in the Confederacy.  As I have already told something about the size of rations.  Bread 10 cents per ration. Beans 10 cents per ration on pint of cooked beans or peas. Bacon very scarce 20 to 25 cents (about two ounces to the ration). Beer five cents a pint. The beer is made of corn meal fermented. Soda water I don't know how it is made 10 cents a cup. Sarsaparilla syrup 10 cents. I do not understand its manufactory.  Cooked rice about four spoonfuls 10 cents. Boiled eggs 25 cents each. Biscuit and butter 25 cents each. Corn meal coffee ten cents per cup. Large yellow tomato

30 to 40 cents each. Salt 5 cents a spoonful. Onions 25 cents apiece. Corn fritters 5 cents each, corn biscuit 5 cents each, peaches 15 to 45 cents according to quality. White peas 25th potatoes very small 1.00 for dozen midling? size 50 cents each. Flour 50 cents per pint. Our currency is greenbacks postage stamps at one cent each. Confederate money does not pass well here at present. It usually sells for one dollar greenback to every five confederate. Outside greenbacks are worth twenty to one.  I read Psalms today.
Friday August 19th
I visited the market again today. Some some grapes but when I inquired the price, "Do you want to buy?" No. "Well, then it's non of your damned business."  While I was straying about to-day I saw a sick man laying in the creek. He was all skin and bones. His reason had left him. And when I took hold of him to help him out, he stared at me with that awful look. And as though he thought I was wronging him, in an injured, piteous, complaining tone, asked me to let him

alone.  Nevertheless I thought it best to help him out and with the help of another soldier we got him upon the bank.  Yet this was all we could do for him. He was naked and thus he is exposed to the cold by night and heat by day until death shall kindly relieve him from his pain.  I have been reading Psalms today.  I like the 127th very much.
Saturday August 20th
I wandered out the prison again today.  I saw the same sick may laying exposed by the side of the creek today.  It rained today. I read Psalms.
Sunday August 21st
Market's about the same. I finished the Psalms today.
Monday August 22nd
Three years ago today I was mustered into the U.S. Service and therefore my time properly expires today but I suppose circumstances will extend it somewhat. I read in the Testament.
Tuesday August 23rd
There has been a good deal of trading with the guard. Read the Testament.

Wednesday August 24th, 25th, 26th, 27th, 28th
Read in Testament
Monday August 29th
Report that no parole has been agreed upon. Proposals have been sent to our government but no answer received yet.  Read in the Testament.
Tuesday August 30th
Read in the Testament
Wednesday August 31st
"Read in the Testament. A trade has lately sprung up between the prisoners and the guard. Heretofore the rebel officers have monopolized this trade but the guards have at last got their eyes open and notwithstanding the stringent orders against it will trade with the prisoners."  The effect of this trade was highly beneficial to the prisoners in many ways. One was that the guards were obliged to let the prisoners come over the dead line to trade sometimes and after that they quit shooting men although their orders remained the same. And another was that our aristocrats

could no longer monopolize the trade. I was thus enabled to save the life of Sam Wales and Bob Hopper, and for the time being of Robert Brooks, by trading a gold ring which Sam owned for some sweet potatoes thereby partially curing them of the scurvy though they were all unable to walk when I got the potatoes they were able in a few days to hobble about on canes.
Thursday September 1st 1864
Read in the Testament and visited the boys belonging to the 9th Minnesota.
Friday September 2nd
Read in the Testament and visited the boys belonging to the 2nd Indiana? Cavalry. Many have high hopes of exchange.  Will Edwards is in good spirit over the prospect of a speedy release from this horrid unclear.
Saturday September 3rd
Read in the Testament. Rumors of a battle on the Old Field of Fair Oaks.
Sunday September 4th
Read in the Testament. There are rumors of fighting and victories.

Monday September 5th
Some prisoners came in from Sherman's Army. They report victories. Sherman has taken Atlanta. If he moves in this direction we can't remain here long.  There are more stories about parole. Read in the Testament.
Tuesday September 6th
I read in the Testament. Eighteen detachments received orders to be ready to leave here at a moment's notice. A detachment consists of 270 men which are divided into three messes each of 90 men.  There are 118 detachments in the prison, making in all something near 30,000.  I suppose that fully 5,000 have no species of shelter whatever.  This movement is said to be for exchange.
Wednesday September 7th
Six detachments left her today. I read in the Testament.  After this prisoners continued to leave until on the 13th an accident on the Railroad stopped

the movement. Those who were on the train to which this accident happened were allowed to run about in the corn fields and cane breaks.  Yet so strong was the impression that it was an exchange that no attempt was made to escape. They soon returned into prison and when after hearing one of them tell the circumstance I remarked that I should have made a strike for liberty, he called me a "damned fool."  "When you know you will be exchanged in a few days to run the chances of getting to our lines."  I told him that I did not know certain that I would be exchanged in a few days.  "Well then you are a God damned fool."  But about this time two thousand were exchanged with Sherman.  About the 18th matters began to look gloomy.  At the same time it began to rain, then was cloudy and gloomy until the 21st when it set in and rained a cold drizzly rain at times and hard storms at other until the 24th. The 25th it came cold. I now took a cold and my throat was very sore.
Monday September 25th
"Wonderful cold last night. My gums are all eaten

out with scurvy."  It continued cold during the 26th and in last? we had no more very warm weather while we remained in Anderson.  27th and 28th they removed more prisoners.
Thursday September 29th
"I suffer constantly now with scurvy."
Friday September 30th
"As usual nothing but gloomy imprisonment."
Saturday October 1st 1864
"Here we lay in our misery."  On the 2nd of October I began reading a book called a Description of Africa another called Country Cousins and another called "Least Leaf from Sunny Side". In these I found great relief though my gums pained me continually. All the prisoners on the south side of the creek and many on the north side had left. On the night of the 7th we were to leave but failed. We now suffered greatly from the cold. All the wood which the other prisoners had left was consumed and old worn

out shoes were burned. We found that old shoes make a very hot fire. On the 9th we were reorganized and prepared to remain in Anderson during the winter.  On the 11th, the 14th, and 15th unclear were brought in from Sherman's army. We had now been 3 months in Anderson and were suffering intensely from the cold.  There were now about 5,000 in the prison and the big spring would supply us with water, four or five shed had been built near the north end of the stockade. This they called the hospital but I shall call it the "hostile." But here the sick were all collected. They drew some biscuit a very small allowance and some rice soup. Hood had begun his great movement and the rebel papers were boastful. They had cut of Sherman's retreat. It was difficult to capture a whole army. But they were unclear of all his train. The rebels now allowed fire men from each hundred to go out once a day for wood. This was about the 15th and we suffered less with the cold.  On the 18th I got hold of Robinson

Crusoe. This I continued reading until I had finished it. I had never read it before. While I read his account of his long stay on that island I longed to change situations with him.  By carrying in wood and such things we now had got material enough ahead to begin building a shanty accordingly we fell to work and build it long enough for thirteen of us and two chimneys, one in each end.  Having completed our work we were just congratulating ourselves that as we were thirteen in number.  We would have a chance to send a man out for wood nearly every day and that our chances were tolerable for surviving the winter when on the 30th we received orders to be ready to leave and on the 31st early in the morning we left the stockade. As we went out I saw one of our colored soldiers receiving a flogging by order of Captain Wurtz?.  His crime was that he had attempted to escape and had forged a pass. (Be it understood that they held nearly all the negro prisoners as slaves outside)

they were flogging him to make him confess. I am glad that I have fixed to see the day when the tyrant Wurtz has paid the extreme penalty of his crimes. I am not an advocate of capital punishment but sincerity demands that I shall say I can hear the death of such men as Wurtz with Christian resignation.  When on the 1st of November we arrived in unclear the prospect was indeed gloomy.  We were here placed in another stockade without a stick of wood. We suffered intensely.  A rain set in and lasted until the 4th when the weather became clear and cold. On the fourth we had got arranged and fire of us began and dug a hole, just big enough for us all to be in. We had two blankets or rather thin worn and miserable pieces of things. Every rag we could collect we used to patch them making thread from a small piece of canvas which one of the boys had.
Saturday November 5th
Chances for life seem slim enough. But the rebels now lean to allow us to go out for wood. And as those

prisoners who were here first had plenty of wood they would frequently fail to be at the gate when their names were called to go out and we would watch and when a name was called and there was no one to respond we would answer "here"! And go out in his place in this manner one of our boys on the 7th got a load of prime boughs, and I traded a spoon for some more and I soon 'flanked out' as we called it and got more The other boys doing likewise. In this way by the 15th we had secured boughs and timber enough to cover our hole. Besides, we had a large pile of prime knots to hum and were beginning to think that we should be able to defy the winter. We drew sweet potatoes here sometime, though a very limited quantity but the effect of all this was that we nearl all recovered at least partially from the scurvy. On the 8th of Nov we held n election and out of 4000 votes Lincoln received 934 majority

While we were here sick were taken out and exchanged. One day I was dow on the market watching the various maneuvers when I saw a gaunt, lank, and lean figure moving about "Who wants to buy the ration of beans? Only 5 cts." as a ration of beans was worth ten cents I knew that there was some extraordinary emergency or he would not offer so cheap having no money I followed him at a distance well knowing that he would soon find a purchaser. I did not wait long before a man bought his ration. He started at once for a chuck luck board and bet and lost it the first bet. He then stood and looked like a statue for about two minutes. Then turned and started for the camp and never looked around him until he got to his den. I saw a similar case in Anderson I which a boy sold a comb for 5 cts that was worth 25 and bought a thick molasses candy with the money I told these things at home and people excused the foolishness on the

ground that "the poor fellows" are so near starved to death that they had no reason. "Wow if that were the case instinct would prompt them to eat their rations rather than sell them and gamble away the proceeds. On Monday the 21st of Nov we left the stockade about one A.M. in a hard rain storm and after a great amount of crowding and swarming we got aboard the cars here we received a cracker and a half and about half pound of fresh beef We arrived in Savannah about dark we remaining here until eight or nine oclock. And then left on flat cars down the Gulf R.R. It was a stormy rainy, cold, and gloomy, night and as we rolled along we suffered extremely from the piercing winds. And as I could look into the houses and see the cheerful fires must own that a feeling of envy stole into my heart. At last we stopped on the morning of the 22nd eighty eight miles south

of Savannah at the place called Black Shear Station Tuesday Nov 22nd We lay by the side of the rialroad all day, Share a tolerable fie but nothing to eat. The weather is clear, cold, and windy. My pants and blouse, you may well judge are poor since they have been worn ever since February constant near. I have no blanket of my own but one shirt I can wear and that is more than a year old, no socks but I am in luck to have a good pair of shoes "On the 23rd we got a ration of bread. After 54 hour without anything to eat. Weather continued clear, cold, and windy until about the 1st of Dec. On the 24th of Nov we moved out into the woods. On the 26th they took our a thousand prisoners and paroled them. But I have since learned that they were sent to South Carolina instead of to our unclear. On the 29th another thousand went out but returned on the 2nd of December, they returned after having

been as far a Savannah they report Sherman within 30 miles of that City and that Burnside has cut the Rail Road between Charleston and Savannah. The weather was beautiful during the latter part of our stay at Blackshear. there also came some clothing from the Sanitary Commission and ten out of each hundred could draw a shirt of pair of pants or blanket but more could draw more than one garment. Of course this benefited bur few. I tried while here to arouse our men to charge the rebel camps, as we could take them easily and march through to Brunswick and 80 miles distant. failing in this I tried to get some one who had a blanket to run away with me. In this I also failed. as you will do gentle reader when you attempt to raise men to action for they will not act. Had I known at that time what I afterwards learned I should

have made good my escape alone. But I feared being retaken and should I go to any other prison without a blanket I must perish.  Hence I was for once in my life "Conservative" and "remained in hot water lest I should be scald."  Forgive me gentle reader this weakness and I promise you on my sacred honor to always henceforward to be "Radical."  If there is anything I mortally detest it is "conservatism".  And I can call my fearfulness to act on this occasion by no other name.  Well time rolled on and on. The 11th of December we were all crowded aboard cars 85 men in one small car thus like brutes we were rolled to Thomasville where we arrived on the 12th and a miserably cold time we had of it.  And although we arrived at 3a.m. it was about noon before we could get any wood to burn.  About the 16th I saw a rebel paper. It told of fighting and raiding near Savannah, fighting near Nashville, and claiming rebel victory.  On the

17th we received two days ration of hard bread with a caution to keep them on hand. And on the 19th we left Thomasville marched in a northerly direction crossed the Ockolockony River and camped after having marched about 10 miles. The weather was now like summer.  On the 20th it rained and on the 21st it turned cold and continued so during the rest of our march which ended on the 23rd at Albany Ga where we got aboard the cars and were unclear in Old Camp Sumter Anderson on the 24th. During this march we often waded water over our knees and then the cold wind would strike us with a chilling effect.  On the night of the 22nd Peter Berg escaped.  Again our prospects were very gloomy rain often

poured in torrents always cold and chilling then would come cold clear or cloudy days in which the wind would sweep through our tattered garments on our skeleton frames with an effect that was by no means pleasant.  Here my Christmas and New Year will not be forgotten soon.  These were times of the keenest sufferings. Reader my pen is weak, but when the next cold howling rain falls in winter just stand in it for two hours only with clothes that have been worn a year in hard service, and then think of soak? rain every day and night for a week at a time, and when it clears you are only blessed with a cold piercing? wind then perhaps you can form some idea of our sufferings. The great noise in the north has been about starvation in those prisons as though that were

their worst features.  The starvation was a light matter compared to our other sufferings and it was bad enough. 'Tis true. "Our bread was such as captives tears Have moistened many a thousand years Since man first pent his fellow men Like brutes within an iron den."  Yet this was light compared to the loss of our liberty and the cold and bitter storms that beat on our worn frames.  Let anyone who complains at his lot, but think for a moment and be content. Whenever I am inclined to gloom, I think of those days and laugh at all present trouble.  My jaws having recovered from the scurvy I had a most voracious appetite and I could grind a bone to pieces in my teeth.  I have since adopted the theory that hunger strengthens the muscles

of the jaw. For although I have naturally strong jaws and excellent teeth I know I could not now make an impression on a bone which I could then crush in my teeth with ease.  When we drew rations of beef we sometimes got a bone and of course it would not do to waste it so we just eat it.  On the 4th of January I was admitted to those sheds called hospital which were in the north end of the stockade. I now had the rheumatism and suffered constantly from it.  But these miserable barracks and the short rations I got there were worse than with the boys in camp.  I therefor on the 8th returned to camp and succeeded in trading my shoes for a miserable old blanket. And being out of house and home I got into a tent with Sam Wales. Thus we have each in his turn saved the other's life. During January many took the oath of allegiance

to the rebels.  Do you blame them reader? If you do I don't .  One named Baker belonging to our battalion talked of it and once went to the gate to do so.  But came back with tears in his eyes and said when he thought of home he couldn't do it.  "Tears," you say, "he was weak."  I tell you he was as daring a man as ever tread a battlefield.  And a man of iron nerve. But here he was without protection and he died true to his country.  Let none dare call this man weak because he could find a tear.  He perished a victim to rebel cruelty and his own fidelity.  He perished for you and me reader. Let us honor the name of James Baker.  On the 18th of February 700 prisoners came in from Tennessee. They reported Hood's Army as nearly annihilated.

Reports of successes continually, after this, poured upon us. This served to gladden our hearts and cheer our sad condition.  From the 25th of February until the 3rd of March we had a continuous rain.  Then came more reliable reports about an exchange than any which had hither to come to us.  Accompanied with an increase of rations until we finally got over a quart of meal a day and a pound of beef or half pound of pork.  Now while I was congratulating myself on having lived through the winter to brighter days and could soon be exchanged I suddenly took the diarrhea which afterward changed into the flux.  I was taken on the 10th of March.  This brought me to the point of death for many days.  I could not walk thee [three?] rods, and I took such abuse as dying men were want to take in that den of devils.  "Nameless here forever more" shall be those who abused me, I merely write it that those at home may know the manner of nearly every prisoner's death who perished in Andersonville.

One used such language as the following "By G-d if I was as helpless as you I'd kill myself." Another threatened to flog me, But what can you expect of a man who will quarrel with, and curse his brother about a piece of bread. I was on the point of death just like others that did die. Yet I always felt that my time had not yet come and these abuses aroused my indignation. In fact from the time we got back to Andersonville during all the rest of my imprisonment I was weak and crippled with rheumatism which subjected me to similar abuses. On one occasion I was struck in the back with a stick of wood By a little but very mean Misourian. I caught him and held him until he abandoned fighting. I dared not strike him for should I whip him, no matter how just the cause he being smaller than I would be sufficient reason for

someone to take it up and should he be whipped another would take his place and thus the big one would eventually get the worst of it.  So I just held him till his rage passed over and let him go.  Though he needed a whipping very badly.  On the 17th of March they took out the first lot of prisoners.  These went to Vicksburg.  They were generally such as could raise money enough to buy the first chance out.  I of course could not come under that head and this I look upon, as, saving the fact of my life being spared though that spell of sickness, the first of a vast number of the most wonderful interpositions of Providence in my favor.  Why he interposed in favor of one so unworthy I know not but read the following narrative and see if it does not look like the hand of God.  Most of those prisoners who bought out I believe were blown up on the Sultana.  Well finally on the

5th of April we left the Stockade I presume rather that it was on the 6th at any rate my diary was one day behind the real time when I reached our gunboats. On the following day we camped near Blue Springs, We had gone to Albany on the cars. Blue Springs is indeed worth visiting It is several rods across it and it boils up in a most magnificent manner. It is of an indigo blue to all appearances when you look into it but on dipping it up it is as clear as you could wish and very good to the taste. A stream several rods wide and very deep runs from it. On the 8th we left the Spring and marched about 15 miles. Of course I was unable to keep up with the column But while the column would be resting I by keeping a rightful place I would over take it. One of the fellows who had often abused me before, since I had been sick, now "Bond's as resolute as an old cow." This stung me but I knew

that he had never faced one tenth what I had faced. I held him in the most supreme contempt. But notwithstanding the resolution with which these insults inspired me. I was not able to keep up after noon. And when I began to lag a rebel guard threatened to bayonet me however finding that I could not be scared into a fester gait he left me and I was taken up by one of the wagons.

The Escape Saturday April 8th "We march about fifteen miles; turn back: and I give them the slip." Now, after I had got into one of the sick wagons just before sun down, an order was received  to return to Andersonville. It was now warm weather and I no longer feared perishing from cold, should I be retaken and separated from  my companions. As soon as we are turned back I resolved to escape or make a glorious failure. And when I thought of "Bond's as resolute as an old cow" I was more than confirmed in my resolution to accomplish an end which though so desirable the author of the above remark would never have the courage to attempt. I fell to studying on the best mode of proceeding. I was at that time blind as soon as it began to grow dark * Many prisoners, myself included, had, through weakness, become affected with what we soldiers called "moon-blindness." I could seemingly see as well as ever by daylight but was almost totally blind at night. The moon was nearly full. In fact I know it was full two nights later because it was then eclipsed. But moonshine is very little better than total darkness to one so affected. Once can see a fire light at a distance. This was a useful fact to me that night. Hence it would be a dangerous business to attempt to run the guard, especially as I could not run even as fast as an "old cow." Nevertheless I was resolved that this should be the end of my imprisonment. I pondered on some plan to deceive

the guards. Weakened and worn by disease and suffering, I at times almost felt like abandoning the attempt, and the again i saw nothing but death before me, should I return to prison. And here I wish to say that I had great temptation to go into camp and risk running the guard merely because by so doing I would have an opportunity to cook a pint of peas which I had traded my hard bread for. so much will hunger and suffering weaken man's resolution. Now while I was pondering as to what course to pursue,  Providence kindly threw within my grasp the desired opportunity. And this you many well suppose I was not slow to grasp. It was now dark and I could see the light's ahead where the column was going into camp. The wagons were stopped and and knowing that there was wood by the side of the road I pretended that I knew it not, but asked one of the guards If there was any "wood out there" remarking that I was "So blind I couldn't see." "Yes sir there's plenty of wood there" "Well I guess I'll get out and pick up an armful. I can get

into camp against these wagons will" Now as there was a guard along the whole train he of course raised no objections, accordingly I got out of the wagon and stumbling around much more than was necessary the guard soon began to suppose that there could be no danger of such blind creature and paid no farther attention to me. I moved on toward the camp picking up wood. But when my load of wood became too heavy I would lay a stick down and pick it up again in the way I came along very nicely on the out side of the guard keeping a watch for carelessness and this was soon afforded me. Where several guards were sitting on a log facing the road and talking busily here I stole entirely away from the guard line and now being at least fifty yards from any rebel I dropped my wood and nlaked? off. The very thought that I was again a free man inspired me with new courage. But I was to faint and weak to travel far and after having proceeded about half a mile I laid down to rest. And think what step it was best to take. I think it was nearly

midnight when I had entirely matured my plan and fell asleep.  So many had attempted to escape but had been brought back that the chances seemed slim enough. I first thought to start for St. Marks.  If I go there I will travel by land.  If I travel by land I will take the woods and travel by daylight.  For the great mistake of our prisoners has been that they have tried to travel on roads by night and of course they would run on to a rebel jacket and be captured again.  I thought to go by land to Eastern Florida thinking that perhaps the longest route would be shortest.  But no cause received the approval of judgment so well as Flint River by night in a boat.  When this was once resolved upon I saw that it would be necessary to cross the road before daylight next morn.  That I might not be seen.  Accordingly about 2 o'clock I should think by the moon I rose and moving half mile in the direction of Thomasville turned and crossed the road proceeded half mile farther and

laying down was soon asleep.  I woke no more until after daylight.  As I slept during this entire escape I had in my dreams, all the time, my undertaking on my mind.  Just after daylight I was awakened by some persons talking in a low voice near me.  I gently raised the blanket unclear from over my eyes saw two men passing near me.  One of them appeared to be a rebel soldier with his cartridge box and belt but no gun, the other seemed like one of our prisoners as they passed not twenty feet from me one said, "We will wait here till our men come along."  What he meant I know not, but at any rate I was glad to see them pass on without noticing me and as they were traveling toward the road I was soon traveling in the other direction toward the river.  I was compelled to "flank" and good many rebel houses during the days march.  It proved to be only six miles to Flint River yet this was a full day's march for me.  I was laying in the top of a fallen pin tree just before sunset not far from the road where I could watch any movement that might be made.

near me, and yet was measurably secure myself.  I saw three darkies walking along the road.  They stopped just opposite me and seated themselves on the fence. I at length resolved to speak to them. I rose and started toward them they saw me and as they turned their faces toward me one of them looked so much like a white man that I feared I was taken, but on approaching closer he appeared to be a quadroon.  Son most likely of some Christian southern gentleman, nevertheless I felt sure he was loyal not withstanding his rebel father.  I told them my circumstances and that I wanted to get a boat on Flint River.  "Well you just hide here till dark and dog on'ed if some of us don't help you."  I then asked how far to Flint River and found that it was only a mile.  They told me that they had a boat which had been made to bring hogs across the river and that I could take it.  Accordingly I hid and after dark they came with bread, meat, and sweet potatoes.  We went to the river and although the boat was a miserable leaky concern, I embarked and bidding my benefactors farewell.

was soon floating down the river.  My boat I soon found was so leaky that I was compelled to bail all the time with a quart cup to prevent swamping. This I had no opportunity to attend to steering it.  Besides, as I have said before, I was so blind that I could see but a short distance ahead.  Nevertheless by the will of God I was permitted to float in safety to a place where it was proper I should be wrecked.  Just near midnight I came to a place where there was a ferry and the wire that was stretched across the river came near taking my head but I saw it time enough to stop so that it only knocked my cap off.  Shortly after I came to an island in the river which was covered with willows and overflowed with water.  Just at the head of this island was a log with one end in the mud at the bottom and the other leaning up stream.  Just by the side of it stood a willow and it bent down stream with the current.  The bow of my boat struck the log and the stern swung around against the willow, the boat dipped? water with the shock and then remained solid.  I stepped forward and placing my paddle
