against the end of the log endeavored to push the boat away from the log when quick as thought it capsized as it turned over it caught on to the log and climbing on it took hold of the willows to steady myself and looked down on the hopeless wreck of my unclear.  Here strange to say a dozen ludicrous thoughts flashed across my mind.  I thought of the time Don Quixote and Sancho Panza were wrecked at the mills.  And I laughed heartily at the thought of being the subject of a comic sketch by "our special artist on the spot."  After these sportive? ideas were passed I began to reflect seriously on my condition.  I took my haversack and blanket and hung them on the willow which was a very foolish move as they might have led to my discovery before the next night.  The proper way would have been to throw them in the river.  I had Ned's picture, a Testament, and my diary.  I took them out of my pocket and raised my unclear to throw but stopped, reflected, and returned them to my pocked.  I then looked

at the shore the distance was short but the current was rapid and I was weak as well as the water cold.  I thought of alligators and then plunged in.  It was as much as I could do to reach the short and when I did reach it, it required my utmost efforts to ascent the bank.  I found myself on a large plantation and started in search of the house.  After traveling nearly a mile I heard someone singing and proceeding in that direction I found that the darkies were just breaking up meeting.  As I was climbing the fence near their quarters I saw a colored woman nearby.  She ran from me.  I called to her.  Told her I was a Yankee unclear but all to purpose she continued her retreat and I followed down to the quarters where I stated my case and was soon in one of their huts by a good fire.  Here I learned that had my boat passed the island in safety it would have been wrecked on some rocks just below.  These rocks were on the left bank of the river and to this bank I had hitherto hovered.  I further learned that there was an excellent boat a short distance up the

river. One of the young men agreed to show it to me on the following night.  It might be on the other side of the river but I could swim the river and get it.  this being resolved on it was next resolved that I should occupy one of their shanties during the following day accordingly when morning dawned.  I repaired to the hut proposed and crawling under a bed I remained until night.  But during the day I was attacked with a violent fever so that when night came I did not feel like swimming the river and therefore we went nearly two miles up the river and took another boat.  They described the place where I would find the other boat and as this was leaky I resolved to secure the other.  I proceeded down and examined on the right bank of the river but it probed to be on the left.  Here I left the other and now felt secure in the possession of a good bateau and so I descended the river until daylight.  It was not the 10th of the month, 9th according to my diary.  I lay in the woods all day.  On the 11th I again lay by without accident and again descended the river.

On the 12th I lay over near a ferry and when night approached I went to some darkey huts hear their master's dwelling.  While I was trying to get near the huts a dog barked at me for a long time but I remained quiet at length.  A negro woman came near and I called her to me.  She gave me some eggs, and sent a young negro boy to me.  She stole some onions from "Massa Garden" for me. He also brought me a cup of milk from Massa's table.  I left them with many good wishes for their welfare and they on their part sent with me their accustomed prayer.  "I pray to God you may get safely to your people."  After reaching the river I again renewed my voyage.  But soon came to a place where a house stood near the river.  I landed hoping to find some colored gentlemen from whom I could get information concerning the river below and also perhaps I might seize on some more onions and lay in a stock large enough to last during the remainder of my journey.  I passed a log cabin which I supposed was inhabited by negroes and having gone up near the mansion prowled around for a while without

finding any clothes hanging out.  I started back to my boat when I was just opposite the log house the dogs for the first time began to bark and I heard someone coming to the door but as I supposed it would be a darkey.  I stood near the door, it opened and there I found myself confronted by a white man at once my mind was made up to do all the talking myself and thus confound him.  I"I lost my way I guess."  "Where do you want to go?"  " I? how far is it to Bainbridge?"  "Eighteen miles.  do you want to go there." "Yes, Sir?" "Don't you know the road?" "No Sir I have never been down on this side of the river and I have lost my way?"  "Well the road is about three quarters of a mile out in this way?"  "Thank you Sir, good night."  I left him before he could have time to resolve on any course to pursue moving a short distance in the direction he had indicated.  I flanked round to my boat and was soon traveling down the river.  On the 13th it rained and strange to say this day I stopped near an old

shelter of some kind and slept well during the whole day.  In fact I slept so well that I did not wake until sometime after dark.  I then returned to my boat and proceeded down the river.  On the 14th I stopped near a grove of cypress, hickory and other hard wood timber near a big plantation.  My stock of provisions now being out, I resolved just before sundown to go up and reconnoiter.  As I was proceeding carefully along with my eyes turned in every direction, watching for human foes I heard something buzz at my feet and looking down there was a rattlesnake.  I think no more than a foot and a half from me.  Why he did not bite me I could never divine, but you may be assured I soon gave him a wide track.  Having reconnoitered by daylight after dark I proceeded to the darkey quarters here I got a supply of provisions and I found a darkey who formerly worked as a deck hand on one of the river boats. From him I learned something of the river below and then having regained my boat I continued my journey.

On the 15th I lay over in an excellent hiding place being surrounded by swamps and thick woods.  I woke once during the day and saw a snake of a beautiful silver color and about five feet in length crawling near to me.  Having secured a club I attacked him and having battered his head until I supposed him dead I paused when he took a sudden start and run under and old log nearby.  I turned the log over and stuck the end of a stick through his head.  I then threw him out to one side with the sick yet in his head, lay down, and fell asleep.  When I woke I looked for his snakeship but could find him nowhere about, the stick I had inserted in his caput was there but on it was no serpent.  Whether he had life enough to crawl away or whether he was carried away by some kind of prey I leave the reader to judge for himself.  I have heard that the mate of snakes will sometimes carry them off.  This I think is doubtful for I hardly believe in can be proved that snakes go in pairs.  I saw a steamboat

pass along the river but as I was well concealed it created no alarm.  Night coming on I again descended the river.  But I found that I was now in a wild region with few houses and that the river was bordered on every side with swamps but at times I passed a spot where there was dry land, approached the shore and occasionally there was a house and plantation.  As I was again out of provisions and besides I wanted to know how near I was to my journey's end it became necessary for me to see some darkeys.  While I was thus paddling along in hopes of finding a house, daylight overtook me and shortly afterwards I can in full view of a house. As there would be no chance to arrive at the darkey  quarters without passing down the river to some point below the house, I determined to venture a run before the door in plain view as I glided noiselessly down the stream I saw a white man come along up the bank of the river and go in at the door but I was glad to observe that he had not discovered me. I

proceeded to a point a half mile below the house. I here found some reeds and hid my boat.  I then passed along concealed in the cane break in this manner.  I approached to within a few roads of the darkey quarters and nor more than 100 yards of the house.  Here I took my station to watch what might go on.  It was Sunday.  I could see the lords  passing about the place, and I could distinctly see every movement near the darkey quarters.  Presently a negro woman came out of the hut nearest me and came down near the cane break.  I called her and after some hesitation she came to me.  I told her my case, and she went into the house and sent her husband to me.  From him I learned that there was a guard on the left back on the river at Ricco's Bluff twenty five miles below.  I also learned that nearly all the country below was swamp.  He told me that all the rebel guards were on the left bank and of course I resolved to keep the right.  Not finding the old mas as intelligent as I could wish, I asked him

to send some of the other colored people down, but he was so very prudent that he would trust his secret to none but his own family although there were more than thirty darkeys on the plantation.  I often found it so, though no darkey to whom I discovered myself ever showed any inclination to betray me.  Each seemed afraid that some other would do so.  When night fell I regained my boat and moved on down the river.  And I think it was about two o'clock a.m. perhaps that approached Rico's Bluff.  As I came near the bluff a friendly fog covered the river so thickly that there was no possible danger of discovery.  I thus passed the bluff without the least alarm though I was afterwards informed by the deserters that the guard always hid themselves during the night for fear of being captured by the deserters.  When day came I lay by in a barren desolate spot covered with reeds and blackberry briars.  I here broke a cane from one of the reeds intending to carry it home as a trophy but I lost it at Apalachicola.  When evening came I again

proceed down the river keeping the right bank for fear of rebels.  But now I observed small streams running out into the swamp and others returning into the main river.  I had not proceeded far in this manner before I came to a place where there seemed to be an island in the river.  At the head of it was a drift of timber thorough which the water roared terribly

I knew not to which side to steer nor in fact had I long to decide the waters carried to the right of it into a narrow channel.  I had not more than had time to congratulate myself on my escape from weak when I became alarmed at not returning into the main river again.  I turned my boat but could not propel it against the current so I turned again and proceeded carefully down the stream watching on either side for some outlet of escape.  I saw little streams come in through the swamps and other little streams go out, as I advanced my fears increased especially as the channel seemed to grow narrower.  I now feared that the stream would leak out into the main river by little streams and leave me with no means of escape in the midst of a cypress swamp.  But as this was not a place for stopping I resolved to be "radical" and push ahead.  I did so and my fears were soon realized but in a different manner from what I had anticipated.  I had proceeded about 7 miles in this channel when

my boat ran on a drift of logs extending across the entire channel.  I was now at a loss to know what to do and being tired I deemed it best to lay down and sleep until morning.  But this was accompanied with one difficulty.  The current was very swift here and suppose a log should drift down and striking my boat burst it.  Again a thought of Alligators crossed my mind and then I thought that they would not be so impudent as to attack me in a boat.  So I lay down and slept soundly until morning.  When morning came I rose and examined the drift but found no passage through it.  I now turned my boat upstream with many doubts as to my success but found that I could by picking my way propel my boat up the channel.  After proceeding about two miles I was delighted with the sound of a cowbell on my left (near the right bank of the stream,) and soon after by the noise of someone plowing

I thrust my boat among some cypress trees and sat down to rest and conclude what was best to do while I was seated there.  A boat came out through the swamp a little farther up the stream. There were two ladies and a gentleman in it.  They proceeded downstream and I began to hunt my way for dry land after considerable trouble from my batteau's being stopped by cypress knees.  I reached the dry land and stood in my boat concealed partially by the reeds that skirted the margin of the swamp.  Here I saw the boy plow several rounds before I unclear courage enough to hail him as he was a white boy.  At length I accosted him.  He looked up somewhat surprised and asked me if I was a deserter.
"I belong to the army but am not a deserter."
"Are you going to town?"
"Yes!"
"What company do you belong to?"
Company B 85th Georgia.  What town did you mean?
"Appalachia"
"No I'm not going to Appalachia. The Yankees are down there.
"Oh, I didn't know but you was a deserter."

"Why if I were a deserter I should be afraid to show myself in daytime."
"Well they go in such droves nowadays that they ain't afraid to show themselves any time."
"Are there many around here?"
"No but I have heard that there is out in Washington County."

 After a little further conversation in which I learned that he was an orphan boy living with a widow woman, he invited me to come up and have some dinner. This invitation I gladly accepted as it had now been near twenty-four hours since I had tasted food.  The widow seemed at first not overly well pleased with visitor and talked about the hardships which the war had brought upon her.  I tried to console her with the prospect of a speedy close of the war.  She asked how I thought it would end.  I answered, "The Yankees will soon whip us out."

"I wish they would hurry up and do it then."
After this reply the old lady seemed alarmed lest she had revealed

her true sentiments to a rebel soldier and added, "If we must be conquered the sooner the better."  But I agreed with her so well that she soon talked Union and I did so too while both pretended to be rebel a heart.  
Here I learned that on the river was a channel only half mile above where I lodged on the logs, but that I would be compelled to follow narrow channels for twenty miles and pass through Gum Swamp in which a stranger was sure to be lost.  I had told a great fish story about my regiment having been ordered down to these parts, and I had been on sick furlough &c and thus it was soon resolved that the regiment was going to the obstructions and therefore it would be necessary for me to go back to the main river a distance of five miles.  Well I got dinner and a day's ration besides.  I then moved on up the river this took all the rest of that day and until noon the next.  At last with joy I seated myself in the boat to float down the main river.  I floated happily down the stream, saw

many alligators. One very large one crawled off of a sand bar as I approached him.  I soon after saw that I was near an old fortification.  I approached it carefully and found it vacant.  As I came near it a small alligator crawled off the bank and swam almost within reach of me.  I struck at his head with the paddle but he never deigned to dive.  So, I moved on and left him being too indifferent to stop for such precarious game.  I fastened my boat and ascended the parapet.  On looking around I found it well supplied with dewberries and I found some gourds.  I took the gourds and broke their necks off, removed the seeds and filled them with berries.  Having this provision for my ship I began to search for other plunder.  I found an old comb which I very much needed so I saved it.  I also carried off a letter A made of a bullet as a [?relic?] finding

nothing farther to my advantage and night having fallen I returned to my boat and prepared to pass some mysterious thing ahead called the obstructions of the nature of which I was totally ignorant and which I supposed would be guarded.  I had not gone more than a mile ere the mystery was solved by running on a drift of logs extending across the river. Again I was compelled to lay down and sleep.  And when morning dawned I again turned my boat upstream resolved to return to the widow's and take the land.  As on the upper part of the other stream I was often compelled to approach near the margin of the river and taking hold of the willows pull myself along by the branches, the water being so swift and my boat so large and heavy that I couldn't force it against the current with a paddle.  I found several places along the river where I could pick berries and on these I lived each day assuring myself that as God had shown his providence on each preceding day so he would on this and in this I was right.  For I found berries

in abundance when other food failed and although berries are not very substantial living on which to perform such severe toll yet without them I presume I should have failed and perished in the swamp.  And I now saw that had I not run into that narrow channel I would have known of no way of escape but by paddling twenty five miles up the river to Rico's Bluff, this I could not have done without provisions and hence must have perished.  But God willed that I should escape these evils. Again, had I not been wrecked just as I was perhaps I would have reached these swamps in some miserable leaky boat and then I must have perished.  Again as I feared to show myself to a white man I was resolved when I should reach Appalachicola to venture out on the bay in my boat.  Now if I had done so I might have hit the gunboats and again I might have drifted into the Gulf in the latter event would certainly perish.

After a day and a half's work I reached the cut off again and soon descended to the widow's. Told her that I didn't find my regiment at the obstructions, and that as my furlough was nearly out I guessed I would take the land and report to the nearest company.  To render this all smooth I gave her my boat and a few quarts of blackberries.  I stayed talking with her for some time.  After a spell she asked me whether I had ever seen any deserters.  I told her that I had seen a great number.  She then asked me whether I had reported them.  I told her I had not and did not intend to do so and that I should desert myself were I not afraid to do so.  She soon afterwards left me talking with the boy.  The first thing I know she returned with a large man with black whiskers and black keen eyes, carrying a double barrelled gun. I now supposed I was taken.  He questioned me and I told him the same story; when I had finished he remarked, "Well, old feller, you've had a purty hard time getting down to Appalachia."  "So you thought you'd quit the service, did you?"  "No Sir, I never dreamed of such a thing."  "Well," said he, "You'd better come

with me to my house and stay the night."  "I have no objections."  "Well take some of that bread and meat and come with me.  If the cavalry should find you out here they'd ride you into the ground.  And if you want to get to the Yankees I can put you in a way to get there."  "You're the man for me then."  I returned; and taking the bread and meat I followed him, we proceeded to the swamp and got into his canoe.  After passing a wandering channel for about one and one half miles, we came to dry land covered with a dense forest of trees. In this secure retreat the deserted had a shelter and had been stocking plows.  Shortly after we arrived we heard a whistle and he took his boat and left. Soon after returned with two other deserters with him.  As we were that might sitting seemed a blazing fire, for it was no raining and we were talking, one of the deserters after eyeing me attentively for some time asked, "Well old pardoner haven't you been among the Yankees in your time?"

"I certainly have.  I was captured from the Yankees."  "I thought you was no Southern man."  I remained with the deserters during the night and when morning came I was conveyed four miles down the river by the man who first discovered me.  His name is Samson Whitfield.  The other two were named one John McClellan and another William Red.  After Mr. Whitfield had conducted me or rather conveyed four miles down the river.  He directed me to another deserter four miles farther down the river, this last deserter's mane was Levi Rhaims.  Rhaims was a tall slim man. He appeared in unclear time after my arrival at his residence with the usual appendage of his fellows, namely a double barrelled gun and a unclear shin? bullet pinch?  He was a jovial hospitable good natured man and gave me a hearty unclear promising to convey me to Appalachicola in a few days.  So I remained with him until the 25th of April.  When Mr.

Rhaims, Mr. Foster, Mr. McLellan and embarked in Mr. Rhaim's canoe and proceeded to Appalachicola.  Mr. Rhaims and Foster were going for salt and Mr. McClellan had just heard of the murder of his brother-in-law and was going to see his sister.  Now there is a place on the left bank of the Appalachicola called Bloody Bluff.  At this place the rebels formerly fired on deserters passing the river and to avoid it Mr. Row (the man who had lastly been murdered) had wandered through the channels far to the right and had discovered a passage most intricate indeed, which was called from his name "Row's Cut Off" or "Spider Creek Channel".  The latter name is significant.  The tress marking this channel are blazed but the entrance and outgoings of it are left unmarked so that the uninitiate can have no benefit from it.  In many places it was so extremely narrow that we were obliged to take hold of

the trees on each side and push our canoe through. And I doubt not that there are hundreds of similar channels in these Swamps which have never been discovered. This channel leads into what they call the "Brother," to large channels, so nearly resembling each other as to have acquired that name. Just below the mouth of the Brothers is the great Curlew's nesting place, as we passed they were flapping and fluttering in the reeds as thick as I ever saw pigeons. I estimated that there was a nest every four feet square and we met a man hunting the eggs who told us he had been out in the canebrake 200 yards and that they were as thick that far as as they were along the river and how much farther they extended he did not know. And on the other bank it was the same. They extended along the river for about two miles, now allowing them to be a quarter of a mile wide and two miles long at this rate there would be 864,950 nests and we may safely say

that these would hatch 3,000,000 of birds as there were nearly always four and not infrequently five to each nest. The curlew is a beautiful bird of snowy white except the tip of its wings which are of a deep blue. About midnight we came into Appalachicola about sundown we had stopped at the house of an old woodsman and as he was going to Appalachicola we remained with him until about 10 o'clock and I took passage in his canoe and coming into town I lost sight of my friends the deserters and thus lost some of my relics and was also unable to return to them the poor? pittance of thanks which was all I had to bestow in return for the many kindnesses which they had shown to me. I was directed to Dr. Chapman and accordingly proceeded to his house and called him up. I told him I was escaped from the enemy and

he seized my hand as if I had been an old acquaintance after remaining under his friendly roof during what remained of the night and having a breakfast of good light bread, butter, fish and tea with sugar and milk, we went to the river and seating ourselves in the Dr. boat were soon bounding gayly over the little billows of the bay. And as the shore receded and the long black gunboat with the stars and stripes streaming above her grew larger my bosom began to swell and I could hardly restrain myself. And when at length we arrived and they let down the ladder and I stepped on her clean white deck I exclaimed, "Joy Joy forever, my task is done The gates are passed, and heaven is won,"

One of the first things that greeted me after reaching the fleet was that Lees army had surrendered. The gunboat on which I at first set foot was the "Stars and Stripes" The officers after giving me clothing and after I had bathed sent me down to the strait that connects Appalachicola Bay with the Gulf. And here I was quartered on the "Flag Ship Mahaska" I remained on the Mahaska until the 28th of April at which time the Gun Boat Yucca came to the fleet with news of the murder of our President. and on the 29th in the after noon I was transferred to her. And soon after was on the Gulf bound homeward. I find the following conclusion to my Diary. "And now that I have made my escape a final reality and as the month of April is now gone

I will close this book remarking that the dates for the last month are one day behind hand, which blunder I shall correct if I ever live to copy at large. One of the crew of the Yucca has furnished me with paper to continue my diary Good bye rebels and rebellion Forever, your humble servant D. Bond."
